title: Hillary Clinton Wins Nevada But Loses Her Narrative
authors: Condé Nast, Benjamin Land, Tina Nguyen, Eric Lutz, Joanna Robinson, Drew Fortune, Erin Vanderhoof, Yohana Desta, Joe Pompeo
content:
After a nail-biting final week in which polls showed Bernie Sanders surging , Hillary Clinton secured a modest victory Saturday in the Nevada caucuses , beating the Vermont senator by about five points and proving , for now , that she is still the front-runner for the Democratic presidential nomination . Clinton loyalists seized on the win as vindication of her oft-maligned candidacy , breathing a sigh of relief at having dodged a week of negative press leading up to the next Democratic contest , in South Carolina next Saturday . But the slim margin of victory carries a warning , too : with Clinton and Sanders converging in national polls , the erstwhile nominee-in-waiting will have to fight like hell for every delegate in every state .
Perhaps most critically , the results coming out of Nevada suggest that Clinton ’ s so-called “ firewall ” with minority voters is not nearly as strong as her campaign had hoped . While entrance polls show black voters went 76-22 percent for Clinton—a reassuring number heading into South Carolina—Sanders stole away significant Hispanic support , winning 53 percent of Latinos . That ’ s a worrisome bellwether for Clinton ’ s chances in other Hispanic-heavy Western states , like New Mexico , Colorado , Arizona and California , late-cycle primaries that will give Sanders additional motivation to remain in the race for the long haul .
Despite losing Nevada , the Sanders campaign quickly spun the results as a victory . “ I want to be completely clear with you about what this result means : Nevada was supposed to be a state ‘ tailor made ’ for the Clinton campaign , and a place she once led by almost 40 points , ” Sanders said in a statement Saturday night . “ But today , we sent a message that will stun the political and financial establishment of this country : our campaign can win anywhere. ” Sanders ’ campaign manager , Jeff Weaver , made a similar argument , telling The Washington Post that his loss represents “ tremendous progress , ” considering the odds he had overcome , and suggesting that the “ Clinton firewall ” was not as strong as once perceived .
Hillary Clinton is still the odds-on favorite in South Carolina , where her black supporters are widely expected to carry the former secretary of state to a landslide victory that could finally blunt Sanders ’ momentum . But losing the Hispanic vote in Nevada is a troubling sign for Clinton , whose campaign frequently pointed to Sanders ’ weakness with minority voters in writing off his 20-point blowout in lily-white New Hampshire . Even before the results rolled in Saturday night , the Clinton campaign had been downplaying expectations for her numbers with Latinos , heading off any interpretation that might undermine her argument as the Democratic candidate with the broadest possible support . With another pillar of that narrative again in danger of collapsing , Clinton faces a tough road ahead .
content_original:
After a nail-biting final week in which polls showed Bernie Sanders surging, Hillary Clinton secured a modest victory Saturday in the Nevada caucuses, beating the Vermont senator by about five points and proving, for now, that she is still the front-runner for the Democratic presidential nomination. Clinton loyalists seized on the win as vindication of her oft-maligned candidacy, breathing a sigh of relief at having dodged a week of negative press leading up to the next Democratic contest, in South Carolina next Saturday. But the slim margin of victory carries a warning, too: with Clinton and Sanders converging in national polls, the erstwhile nominee-in-waiting will have to fight like hell for every delegate in every state.

Perhaps most critically, the results coming out of Nevada suggest that Clinton’s so-called “firewall” with minority voters is not nearly as strong as her campaign had hoped. While entrance polls show black voters went 76-22 percent for Clinton—a reassuring number heading into South Carolina—Sanders stole away significant Hispanic support, winning 53 percent of Latinos. That’s a worrisome bellwether for Clinton’s chances in other Hispanic-heavy Western states, like New Mexico, Colorado, Arizona and California, late-cycle primaries that will give Sanders additional motivation to remain in the race for the long haul.

Despite losing Nevada, the Sanders campaign quickly spun the results as a victory. “I want to be completely clear with you about what this result means: Nevada was supposed to be a state ‘tailor made’ for the Clinton campaign, and a place she once led by almost 40 points,” Sanders said in a statement Saturday night. “But today, we sent a message that will stun the political and financial establishment of this country: our campaign can win anywhere.” Sanders’ campaign manager, Jeff Weaver, made a similar argument, telling The Washington Post that his loss represents “tremendous progress,” considering the odds he had overcome, and suggesting that the “Clinton firewall” was not as strong as once perceived.

Hillary Clinton is still the odds-on favorite in South Carolina, where her black supporters are widely expected to carry the former secretary of state to a landslide victory that could finally blunt Sanders’ momentum. But losing the Hispanic vote in Nevada is a troubling sign for Clinton, whose campaign frequently pointed to Sanders’ weakness with minority voters in writing off his 20-point blowout in lily-white New Hampshire. Even before the results rolled in Saturday night, the Clinton campaign had been downplaying expectations for her numbers with Latinos, heading off any interpretation that might undermine her argument as the Democratic candidate with the broadest possible support. With another pillar of that narrative again in danger of collapsing, Clinton faces a tough road ahead.
